comms: Not included in the database because the combination of encoding devices for X and Y [GEN_NOM] happens to be identical to that observed in the transitive pattern, whereas syntactically, the encoding pattern here does not align with regular transitive clauses.
comms_internal: The was a long disussion between Michael Daniel and Sergey Say on this pattern and whether it should be included. There are syntactic tests that differentiate between transitive and intransitive patterns, but they are not based on flagging and indexing only. For this reason, it would have been illegitimate to tag this pattern as GEN_NOM and at the same to not consider it as transitive. Not including the sentence at all emerged as the best practical solution.

The nominative flagging of X also persists in perfective contexts, Махlаммад ийнди Расулдущал - Магомед подрался с Расулом.

sentence: Maħammad dak’ maˁš qana-j ur Rasul-du-j
comms_internal: Cf. 111. This is an interesting construction. The X argument is not encoded as a regular NP-internal possessor. Arguably, the original name of the body part has been reanalyzed as a sui generis preverb. We assume – with the lack of evidence to contrary – that X is a regular nominative subject, not a hanging argument etc. Note that the speaker spelled the name of the body part together with the predicate.
